intro: Wulfenia carinthiaca var. rohlenae, commonly known as the Rohlen's wulfenia, is a flowering plant native to high-altitude regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family, characterized by its showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils, often in arid or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are usually narrow and linear, adapted to reduce water loss in dry conditions. The species is notable for its ecological significance in supporting local pollinators and contributing to alpine biodiversity.
